questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of left-sided groin pain and difficulty walking for 3 weeks. He reports having pain at rest and increased pain with activity. He recently started playing flag football but does not recall any trauma. His father says that he was healthy during his first year of life but then started having recurring episodes of joint and bone pain, some requiring hospitalization. The patient and his family immigrated from India 2 years ago. He is at the 25th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Examination shows tenderness over the lateral aspect of the left hip with no swelling, warmth, or erythema. There is pain with passive internal rotation of the left hip. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Leukocyte count is 9000/mm3. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of the patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transient synovitis is a common cause of self-limited hip pain and limping in children. Episodes can be recurring and boys are affected twice as often as girls. However, this condition typically affects children < 10 years of age, and is associated with a recent history of upper respiratory tract infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Although untreated developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) can cause hip pain in older children, symptoms typically start earlier, with a history of abnormal hip abduction during infancy and hip pain and limping from 18 months of age. Pain in DDH usually becomes chronic with consistent symptom progression, unlike this patient's history of episodic joint pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Impaired skeletal growth can be a complication of SCD (due to premature closure of the long bone epiphyses) and lead to hip pain in children. Although this patient is in the lower percentiles for height and weight, hip pain from skeletal abnormalities is typically chronic. This patient's subacute hip pain is more likely the result of a different complication of SCD.

D) INCORRECT:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is a common hip disorder in adolescents and affects boys more often than girls. Most patients present with a chronic or acute-on-chronic course with recurrent episodes of nonspecific hip and/or knee pain and limping. However, even in chronic SCFE, the course of the disease is typically much shorter than this patient's, whose symptoms started when he was a toddler. In addition, this patient does not have the typical risk factors for SCFE (e.g., obesity or tall and thin stature, which indicates a rapid growth spurt).

E) INCORRECT:

Although osteomyelitis can be a complication of SCD (due to functional asplenia) and lead to hip pain in children, it is usually accompanied by systemic findings (e.g., fever, chills, leukocytosis). This patient's isolated hip pain is more likely the result of a different complication of SCD.

F) INCORRECT:

Stress fractures are caused by repetitive applications of force (usually from overtraining) and most commonly affect the tibia and metatarsal bones. Although this patient recently started playing flag football, there is no evidence of excessive training. Furthermore, stress fractures involving the hip are very rare.

G) INCORRECT:

Although septic arthritis can be a complication of SCD (due to functional asplenia) and lead to hip pain in children, it is usually accompanied by systemic (e.g., fever, chills, leukocytosis) and local findings (joint swelling, erythema). This patient's isolated hip pain is more likely the result of a different complication of SCD.

H) CORRECT:

Avascular osteonecrosis of the femoral head can be a complication of SCD and typically manifests between 7–15 years of age. Osteonecrosis is caused by trabecular bone infarction from RBC sickling and vaso-occlusion. The femoral head is commonly affected because of poor collateral blood supply. In a patient with SCD, subacute hip pain without systemic symptoms is characteristic of avascular osteonecrosis.
questions.hint: This patient's groin pain and exam findings suggest a pathology involving the hip. In combination with an immigration history from a country where sickle cell trait is common, his history of multiple hospitalizations for episodes of joint and bone pain should raise suspicion for sickle cell pain crises due to sickle cell disease (SCD).

questions.text: A 13-year-old African American boy is brought to the physician because of a 4-week history of left groin and buttock pain. The pain is worse with activity but also present at rest. He has had many episodes of abdominal, back, and chest pain that required hospitalization in the past. He is at the 20th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), blood pressure is 115/82 mm Hg, and pulse is 84/min. Examination shows tenderness over the lateral aspect of the left hip with no swelling, warmth, or erythema. There is pain with passive abduction and internal rotation of the left hip. Leukocyte count is 8,600/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is a common hip disorder in adolescent males and can also present with pain and limited range of motion. However, this patient's low weight and absence of family history make SCFE unlikely. His underlying sickle cell disease, on the other hand, makes a different diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with sickle cell disease are at increased risk of septic arthritis due to functional asplenia (which results from recurrent infarction of the spleen). Septic arthritis can also manifest with severe hip pain and limited range of motion, which are seen in this patient. However, additional symptoms such as fever, joint swelling, and erythema would also be expected. His normal leukocyte count makes this diagnosis unlikely as well.

C) INCORRECT:

Although osteosarcoma can cause pain and limited range of motion in adolescents, it typically involves the distal femur or the proximal tibia. Proximal femoral osteosarcoma is extremely rare. Furthermore, patients with sickle cell disease are not at increased risk of osteosarcoma and are more likely to experience a different complication.

D) CORRECT:

Avascular osteonecrosis of the femoral head is a common complication in patients with sickle cell disease and typically manifests between 7–15 years of age. This adolescent boy's subacute hip pain and lack of systemic symptoms are characteristic of avascular osteonecrosis, which is due to trabecular bone infarction from RBC sickling and vaso-occlusion. The femoral head is commonly affected as a result of poor collateral blood supply. Other risk factors for avascular osteonecrosis of the femoral head include glucocorticoid use, alcohol use, autoimmune diseases (e.g., SLE, antiphospholipid syndrome), and Gaucher disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Transient synovitis is a common cause of self-limited hip pain and limping in children and is often preceded by upper respiratory tract infection. However, most patients with transient synovitis are slightly younger (< 10 years), and this patient's underlying sickle cell disease makes a different diagnosis more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with sickle cell disease are at increased risk of impaired skeletal growth. The etiology is multifactorial and is at least partially due to premature closure of the long bone epiphyses. Although there is evidence of impaired growth in this patient based on his low percentile in height and weight, it would be unlikely to cause subacute, unilateral hip pain.
questions.hint: This patient's pain and examination findings suggest pathology involving the hip. His previous hospitalizations for painful episodes are consistent with underlying sickle cell disease (SCD).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-week history of gradually increasing bilateral groin pain. The pain worsens with movement and after prolonged periods of standing. She used to run 5 km (3 miles) two times per week but has now stopped exercising due to the pain. She reports no history of trauma. Four weeks ago, she had rhinosinusitis treated with amoxicillin. Two months ago, she was diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus that is currently treated with prednisone and hydroxychloroquine. Family history is unremarkable. She drinks 2–3 glasses of wine on weekdays and occasionally more on weekends. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows remnants of a healing malar rash. There is pain and a limited range of active and passive motion in both hip joints. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the pelvis is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of the femoral heads

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteomyelitis can develop from the hematogenous spread of bacteria (e.g., due to rhinosinusitis), and this patient's immunosuppression resulting from lupus treatment (prednisone) is a risk factor for osteomyelitis. However, this infection usually manifests with systemic (e.g., fever, tachycardia, malaise) as well as local (e.g., erythema, warmth) signs of infection in addition to pain. Moreover, x-ray of the affected bone usually shows soft tissue swelling, osteopenia, and a periosteal reaction rather than subchondral lucency, increased bone density, and articular surface irregularity. Finally, the concurrent development of osteomyelitis in both femoral heads is highly unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Lupus arthritis commonly manifests with symmetric polyarticular pain involving the knees, carpal joints, and finger joints. Hip involvement is uncommon. In addition, arthritic pain is usually migratory (improving in one joint within 24 hours and subsequently developing in another joint) and x-ray of the affected joint typically shows soft tissue swelling and periarticular osteoporosis, not subchondral lucency. Moreover, this patient has responded to therapy and shows no other signs of an acute systemic lupus erythematosus flare (e.g., fever, active rash).

C) INCORRECT:

Osteoarthritis of the hip joints can manifest with bilateral limited range of motion and groin pain that worsens during activity. However, x-ray findings consistent with osteoarthritis include osteophytes, subchondral cysts, and subchondral sclerosis, not subchondral lucency. Moreover, osteoarthritis is most commonly seen in adults aged 50–60 years.
Image Description:

AP view

Findings of osteoarthritis include irregular joint space narrowing (1), osteophytes (2), subchondral sclerosis (3), and subchondral cyst formation (4).

D) CORRECT:

Avascular necrosis of the femoral head manifests with limited range of motion in the hip joint and uni- or bilateral groin pain that worsens with movement or weight-bearing. Some patients also experience thigh or buttock pain, nocturnal pain, pain at rest, and/or pain in other involved joints (e.g., knees or shoulders). X-rays are often normal in the early stages of avascular necrosis of the femoral heads, in which case an MRI should be obtained to establish the diagnosis. Typical x-ray findings (on frog-leg and lateral views) include increased femoral head density, sclerosis, and cysts, as well as subchondral lucency (crescent sign), which indicates a subchondral fracture.

The disease often progresses quickly in adults and most patients require surgical management (e.g., core decompression, bone grafting, total hip arthroplasty) to maintain hip mobility and relieve pain. Supportive care (e.g., analgesia, crutches/walker, regular follow-up) can be considered for asymptomatic patients in whom only a small part of the femoral head (< 15%) is affected.

E) INCORRECT:

Femoral head stress fractures can manifest with groin pain, but they are extremely uncommon. X-rays of stress fractures are typically normal during the first 3–4 weeks. After this time, x-rays show a periosteal reaction or changes in bone density, not articular surface irregularity.
questions.hint: The combination of increased femoral head density on hip x-rays, articular surface irregularity, and subchondral lucency (crescent sign) suggests a condition associated with glucocorticoids, alcohol use, and systemic lupus erythematosus.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man reports a 2-month history of right hip pain with weight-bearing. The pain has progressively worsened during the past 2 weeks. He has a history of systemic lupus erythematosus that has been treated with hydroxychloroquine and prednisone. His prednisone doses have ranged from 10 mg to 30 mg daily for the past year; he currently takes 10 mg daily.
On examination, his gait is antalgic, offloading his right leg. Passive range of motion of both hips and knees are preserved.
A radiograph of the right hip shows patchy sclerosis, areas of demineralization, and small cysts in the right femoral head.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient?

choices.text: Order MRI of the right hip
Schedule fluoroscopy-guided arthrocentesis of the right hip
Order bone mineral densitometry of the hip and spine
Initiate a trial of physical therapy and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus is associated with an increased incidence of osteonecrosis (avascular necrosis of bone); patients treated long-term with glucocorticoids are at especially high risk. Early radiographic features of osteonecrosis include areas of demineralization (often just beneath the cortex) and patchy sclerosis; however, because these findings are not specific for osteonecrosis, the most appropriate diagnostic test (and gold standard) is MRI of the affected hip. MRI allows for correct staging of osteonecrosis, which guides management.

Key learning point: Patchy sclerosis and areas of demineralization in the femoral head of a patient being treated long-term with glucocorticoids is most consistent with a diagnosis of osteonecrosis of the femoral head.

B) INCORRECT:

Increasing the prednisone dose would be appropriate if the patient had a flare of inflammatory arthritis, but monoarticular hip pain is not a common presentation of arthritis due to lupus.

C) INCORRECT:

Fluoroscopy-guided arthrocentesis would be appropriate if imaging of the hip showed an effusion and/or signs of joint destruction concerning for an infected joint; however, the subacute presentation without accompanying systemic signs makes a septic joint unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Bone mineral densitometry is appropriate to diagnose and monitor patients who take long-term glucocorticoids for osteopenia and osteoporosis, but it does not diagnose fracture or other causes of pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug treatment would be appropriate in a patient who has osteoarthritis of the hip, after osteonecrosis has been excluded.

C) INCORRECT:

D) INCORRECT:

Bone mineral densitometry is appropriate to diagnose and monitor patients who take long-term glucocorticoids for osteopenia and osteoporosis, but it does not diagnose fracture or other causes of pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug treatment would be appropriate in a patient who has osteoarthritis of the hip, after osteonecrosis has been excluded.
questions.hint: The combination of hip pain with weight-bearing and cystic and sclerotic changes in the femoral head in a patient with systemic lupus erythematosus suggest osteonecrosis of the femoral head.

The pain worsens with movement and after prolonged periods of standing. Four weeks ago, she had rhinosinusitis treated with amoxicillin. X-ray pelvis (anteroposterior view)

Increased density of the femoral heads (green overlay) is accompanied by articular surface irregularity and subchondral lucency (crescent sign; red line overlay).

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy with sickle cell disease is brought to the office because of a 4-week history of left groin and buttock pain. The pain is worse with activity but also present at rest. He is at the 20th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), blood pressure is 115/82 mm Hg, and pulse is 84/min. Examination shows tenderness over the lateral aspect of the left hip with no swelling, warmth, or erythema. There is pain with passive abduction and internal rotation of the left hip. Leukocyte count is 8,600/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is a common hip disorder in adolescent males and can also present with pain and limited range of motion. However, this patient's low weight and absence of family history make SCFE unlikely. His underlying sickle cell disease, on the other hand, makes a different diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with sickle cell disease are at increased risk of septic arthritis due to functional asplenia (which results from recurrent infarction of the spleen). Septic arthritis can also manifest with severe hip pain and limited range of motion, which are seen in this patient. However, additional symptoms such as fever, joint swelling, and erythema would also be expected. His normal leukocyte count makes this diagnosis unlikely as well.

C) CORRECT:

Avascular osteonecrosis of the femoral head is a common complication in patients with sickle cell disease and typically manifests between 7–15 years of age. This adolescent boy's subacute hip pain and lack of systemic symptoms are characteristic of avascular osteonecrosis, which is due to trabecular bone infarction from RBC sickling and vaso-occlusion. The femoral head is commonly affected as a result of poor collateral blood supply. Other risk factors for avascular osteonecrosis of the femoral head include glucocorticoid use, alcohol use, autoimmune diseases (e.g., SLE, antiphospholipid syndrome), and Gaucher disease.

Key learning point: Avascular necrosis of the femoral head is a common complication of sickle cell disease due to bone infarction from vaso-occlusion.

D) INCORRECT:

Transient synovitis is a common cause of self-limited hip pain and limping in children and is often preceded by upper respiratory tract infection. However, most patients with transient synovitis are slightly younger (< 10 years), and this patient's underlying sickle cell disease makes a different diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with sickle cell disease are at increased risk of impaired skeletal growth. The etiology is multifactorial and is at least partially due to premature closure of the long bone epiphyses. Although there is evidence of impaired growth in this patient based on his low percentile in height and weight, it would be unlikely to cause subacute, unilateral hip pain.
questions.hint: This patient's pain and examination findings suggest pathology involving the hip.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man presents with persistent left hip pain for the past three months. He has a history of sickle cell disease and multiple hospitalizations for painful crises. He denies recent trauma. The pain worsens with weight bearing, and he has difficulty climbing stairs. On examination, internal rotation of the left hip causes significant pain (see reports).

X-ray of the hip: Mild sclerosis of the femoral head
MRI of the hip: Crescent sign near the articular surface

Which underlying process best explains these findings?

choices.text: Hematogenous infection leading to purulent destruction
Chronic cartilage wear and tear due to mechanical stress
Repetitive vascular occlusion leading to subchondral bone infarction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hematogenous infection typically presents acutely with fever and rapid joint destruction, showing lytic lesions on imaging. The patient's mild sclerosis on X-ray and crescent sign on MRI are consistent with avascular necrosis, not an infectious process.

B) INCORRECT:

Immune-mediated synovitis, seen in inflammatory arthropathies, presents with bilateral joint involvement and erosions. The patient's sickle cell disease and imaging findings, including the crescent sign, indicate ischemic changes rather than an inflammatory process.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic cartilage wear and tear from mechanical stress leads to degenerative joint disease, typically showing joint space narrowing and osteophyte formation on imaging. The patient's age and sickle cell disease history, along with the crescent sign on MRI, suggest avascular necrosis rather than mechanical degeneration.

D) CORRECT:

In sickle cell disease, sickled red blood cells intermittently occlude small blood vessels, compromising blood supply to the subchondral bone, particularly in the femoral head. This ischemia leads to bone infarction, characteristic of avascular necrosis. Imaging reveals mild sclerosis on X-ray and the 'crescent sign' on MRI, indicating a subchondral fracture in necrotic bone. The patient's hip pain, worsened by weight-bearing and restricted internal rotation, aligns with this pathophysiological process.

Key learning point: In patients with sickle cell disease, avascular necrosis is a common cause of hip pain due to the occlusion of blood vessels by sickled cells leading to bone ischemia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-week history of gradually increasing bilateral groin pain. The pain worsens with movement and after prolonged periods of standing. Four weeks ago, she was treated with amoxicillin for rhinosinusitis. Two months ago, she was diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus and is currently taking prednisone and hydroxychloroquine. She reports drinking 2–3 glasses of wine on weekdays and occasionally more on weekends. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there is pain and a limited range of active and passive motion in both hip joints. A pelvic x-ray shows increased femoral head density, articular surface irregularity, and subchondral lucency. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of the femoral heads.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lupus arthritis commonly manifests with symmetric polyarticular pain involving the knees, carpal joints, and finger joints. Hip involvement is uncommon. In addition, arthritic pain is usually migratory (improving in one joint within 24 hours and subsequently developing in another joint) and x-ray of the affected joint typically shows soft tissue swelling and periarticular osteoporosis, not subchondral lucency. Moreover, this patient has responded to therapy and shows no other signs of an acute systemic lupus erythematosus flare (e.g., fever, active rash).

B) INCORRECT:

Femoral head stress fractures can manifest with groin pain, but they are extremely uncommon. X-rays of stress fractures are typically normal during the first 3–4 weeks. After this time, x-rays show a periosteal reaction or changes in bone density, not articular surface irregularity.

C) INCORRECT:

Osteoarthritis of the hip joints can manifest with bilateral limited range of motion and groin pain that worsens during activity. However, x-ray findings consistent with osteoarthritis include osteophytes, subchondral cysts, and subchondral sclerosis, not subchondral lucency. Moreover, osteoarthritis is most commonly seen in adults aged 50–60 years.

D) CORRECT:

Avascular necrosis of the femoral head manifests with limited range of motion in the hip joint and uni- or bilateral groin pain that worsens with movement or weight-bearing. Some patients also experience thigh or buttock pain, nocturnal pain, pain at rest, and/or pain in other involved joints (e.g., knees or shoulders). X-rays are often normal in the early stages of avascular necrosis of the femoral heads, in which case an MRI should be obtained to establish the diagnosis. Typical x-ray findings (on frog-leg and lateral views) include increased femoral head density, sclerosis, and cysts, as well as subchondral lucency (crescent sign), which indicates a subchondral fracture.

The disease often progresses quickly in adults and most patients require surgical management (e.g., core decompression, bone grafting, total hip arthroplasty) to maintain hip mobility and relieve pain. Supportive care (e.g., analgesia, crutches/walker, regular follow-up) can be considered for asymptomatic patients in whom only a small part of the femoral head (< 15%) is affected.

Key learning point: Avascular necrosis of the femoral head presents with groin pain, limited hip motion, and x-ray findings such as increased femoral head density, articular surface irregularity, and subchondral lucency (crescent sign).
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis (anteroposterior view)

Increased density of the femoral heads (green overlay) is accompanied by articular surface irregularity and subchondral lucency (crescent sign; red line overlay).

E) INCORRECT:

Osteomyelitis can develop from the hematogenous spread of bacteria (e.g., due to rhinosinusitis), and this patient's immunosuppression resulting from lupus treatment (prednisone) is a risk factor for osteomyelitis. However, this infection usually manifests with systemic (e.g., fever, tachycardia, malaise) as well as local (e.g., erythema, warmth) signs of infection in addition to pain. Moreover, x-ray of the affected bone usually shows soft tissue swelling, osteopenia, and a periosteal reaction rather than subchondral lucency, increased bone density, and articular surface irregularity. Finally, the concurrent development of osteomyelitis in both femoral heads is highly unlikely.
questions.hint: The combination of increased femoral head density on hip x-rays, articular surface irregularity, and subchondral lucency (crescent sign) suggests a condition associated with glucocorticoids, alcohol use, and systemic lupus erythematosus.

questions.text: You are seeing a 13-year-old boy with sickle cell disease who is brought to your clinic because of a 4-week history of left groin and buttock pain. The pain is worse with activity but also occurs at rest. He is at the 20th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36.7°C, blood pressure is 115/82 mm Hg, and pulse is 84/min. On examination, there is tenderness over the lateral aspect of the left hip without swelling, warmth, or erythema. Passive abduction and internal rotation of the left hip elicit pain. His white blood cell count is 8.6 × 109/L (3.5–10.5). Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Avascular osteonecrosis of the femoral head is a common complication in patients with sickle cell disease and typically manifests between 7–15 years of age. This adolescent boy's subacute hip pain and lack of systemic symptoms are characteristic of avascular osteonecrosis, which is due to trabecular bone infarction from RBC sickling and vaso-occlusion. The femoral head is commonly affected as a result of poor collateral blood supply. Other risk factors for avascular osteonecrosis of the femoral head include glucocorticoid use, alcohol use, autoimmune diseases (e.g., SLE, antiphospholipid syndrome), and Gaucher disease.

Key learning point: Avascular necrosis of the femoral head is a common complication of sickle cell disease due to bone infarction from vaso-occlusion, often presenting as subacute hip pain without systemic symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with sickle cell disease are at increased risk of septic arthritis due to functional asplenia (which results from recurrent infarction of the spleen). Septic arthritis can also manifest with severe hip pain and limited range of motion, which are seen in this patient. However, additional symptoms such as fever, joint swelling, and erythema would also be expected. His normal leukocyte count makes this diagnosis unlikely as well.

C) INCORRECT:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is a common hip disorder in adolescent males and can also present with pain and limited range of motion. However, this patient's low weight and absence of family history make SCFE unlikely. His underlying sickle cell disease, on the other hand, makes a different diagnosis more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Transient synovitis is a common cause of self-limited hip pain and limping in children and is often preceded by upper respiratory tract infection. However, most patients with transient synovitis are slightly younger (< 10 years), and this patient's underlying sickle cell disease makes a different diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with sickle cell disease are at increased risk of impaired skeletal growth. The etiology is multifactorial and is at least partially due to premature closure of the long bone epiphyses. Although there is evidence of impaired growth in this patient based on his low percentile in height and weight, it would be unlikely to cause subacute, unilateral hip pain.
questions.hint: This patient's pain and examination findings suggest pathology involving the hip.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presents with an inability to walk on his right leg. He has had several months of progressively worsening right groin pain that radiates to the knee and is exacerbated by weight-bearing. The patient has a history of alcohol use disorder and limited internal rotation of the right hip on examination. An x-ray of the hip is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While hip osteoarthritis can present with groin pain that worsens with activity and limited internal rotation, it typically develops over many years in older adults and is associated with joint space narrowing and osteophytes on imaging. The patient's age, alcohol use disorder, and radiographic appearance showing cystic and sclerotic changes with possible subchondral collapse are not characteristic of typical osteoarthritis.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – Osteonecrosis of the femoral head typically presents with slowly progressive groin pain that radiates to the knee and worsens with weight-bearing, which matches this patient's presentation. Alcohol use disorder is one of the most common risk factors for atraumatic osteonecrosis, accounting for 20–40% of cases. Physical examination findings of limited internal rotation are characteristic. The imaging findings of cystic and sclerotic changes in the femoral head with possible subchondral collapse (crescent sign) are pathognomonic for osteonecrosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Femoral neck stress fractures typically occur in athletes or military personnel engaged in repetitive high-impact activities and present with pain that worsens with activity. The gradual onset over several months and the patient's alcohol use disorder history make stress fracture less likely. Stress fractures would show different imaging findings, such as fracture lines or callus formation, rather than the cystic and sclerotic changes seen in this patient's x-ray.

D) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis presents with an acute onset of symptoms, including fever, joint swelling, warmth, and severe restriction of movement due to guarding. The chronic, progressive course over several months without systemic symptoms makes septic arthritis unlikely. Additionally, septic arthritis would typically show joint effusion and soft tissue swelling on imaging rather than the cystic and sclerotic changes seen in this patient's x-ray.

E) INCORRECT:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) occurs almost exclusively in adolescents aged 10–16 years during periods of rapid growth and is associated with obesity and endocrine disorders. The patient's age makes SCFE very unlikely, as this condition affects the proximal femoral growth plate, which closes after skeletal maturity. For an adult to develop SCFE, an underlying endocrine disorder (e.g., hypogonadism or pituitary tumor) that delayed the closure of their growth plates would have to be present, which is rare. The imaging findings of SCFE would also show displacement of the femoral head relative to the neck, which is not present in this patient's x-ray.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 4-week history of bilateral hip pain that worsens with activity. She has systemic lupus erythematosus treated with prednisone 15 mg daily for 18 months. She was initially evaluated at an outpatient clinic one week ago, where physical examination showed bilateral internal rotation and limited range of motion. Plain radiographs of both hips obtained at that time were normal, and she was scheduled for outpatient MRI. The MRI, completed 3 days ago, shows bilateral femoral head avascular necrosis with subchondral fracture. She returns to the emergency department today because her pain has worsened despite analgesics. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge with NSAIDs and follow-up in 2 weeks
Admit for IV antibiotics and surgical drainage
Obtain bone scan to confirm diagnosis
Prescribe crutches and schedule outpatient physical therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Discharge with NSAIDs alone is inappropriate for confirmed avascular necrosis with subchondral fracture. This represents advanced disease that requires specialized orthopedic management beyond symptomatic treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

IV antibiotics and surgical drainage are treatments for septic arthritis, not avascular necrosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Bone scan is not needed when MRI has already confirmed the diagnosis of avascular necrosis. MRI is the gold standard for diagnosing avascular necrosis and provides superior tissue characterization compared to bone scan.

D) INCORRECT:

While reducing weight-bearing is part of avascular necrosis management, prescribing crutches and physical therapy alone is insufficient for confirmed avascular necrosis with subchondral fracture.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Avascular necrosis with subchondral fracture represents advanced disease requiring urgent orthopedic evaluation. Early detection and prompt treatment significantly improve prognosis by preventing bone collapse and preserving joint function. Bilateral involvement with subchondral fracture indicates the need for immediate surgical consultation to consider interventions such as core decompression or other joint-preserving procedures.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to an urgent care clinic with a 4-month history of progressive, deep, aching pain in his right groin. The pain is exacerbated by walking and standing, and he has recently started using a cane. He has not had any trauma. He has a history of alcohol use disorder. Physical examination shows an antalgic gait. There is no visible swelling or erythema. Passive range of motion of the right hip is limited and painful, especially with internal rotation and abduction. Anteroposterior and frog-leg radiographs of the pelvis are obtained and show only mild osteopenia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging of the hip
Hip arthrocentesis with synovial fluid analysis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While later-stage avascular necrosis may show findings such as the crescent sign (subchondral lucency) or femoral head collapse on plain radiographs, waiting is not appropriate for this patient. He has progressive, debilitating symptoms and a high clinical suspicion for the disease. Delaying the diagnosis postpones necessary treatment and can lead to irreversible joint damage. The goal is to establish a diagnosis promptly.

B) INCORRECT:

CT is excellent for delineating bony architecture and can be useful for assessing the extent of femoral head collapse or detecting a subchondral fracture in later-stage AVN. However, it is less sensitive than a different imaging modality for detecting the early marrow changes characteristic of ischemia before structural damage has occurred.

C) INCORRECT:

A three-phase bone scan can be sensitive for detecting avascular necrosis, often showing an area of decreased uptake ('cold spot') in the early ischemic phase followed by increased uptake during revascularization. However, other conditions, such as stress fractures, infection, or arthritis, can also cause increased uptake. A different imaging modality provides superior anatomical detail and is considered the gold standard for diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

Since plain radiographs are often normal in the early stages of AVN, MRI is the most sensitive and specific imaging modality to confirm early osteonecrosis. It can identify bone marrow edema and ischemic changes well before structural collapse occurs, which would be visible on radiographs. Early diagnosis is crucial because it allows for joint-preserving interventions.
Image Description:

MRI pelvis and hips (T1-weighted; coronal plane) of 31-year-old patient with kidney transplant and new-onset bilateral hip pain

Both femoral heads have well-demarcated areas of heterogeneous signal intensity (green overlay).

In combination with the patient's clinical presentation and history of kidney transplant, these findings are diagnostic for bilateral avascular osteonecrosis of the femoral head. Corticosteroid use is an important risk factor for this condition and may have been causative in this patient as part of immunosuppression after organ transplantation.

E) INCORRECT:

Hip arthrocentesis is indicated when there is suspicion of septic arthritis or crystalline arthropathy. This patient's presentation is not consistent with these conditions. The 4-month duration of symptoms, lack of fever, and absence of local signs of acute inflammation such as swelling or erythema make an infectious or acute inflammatory process highly unlikely. Therefore, this invasive procedure is not warranted.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation, including the risk factor of alcohol use disorder and insidious onset of groin pain with weight-bearing, is highly suggestive of avascular necrosis (AVN) of the femoral head, which is often radiographically occult in its early stages.
